intro: Chloroleucon sempervivum, commonly known as the alpine snowbell, is a perennial flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves and bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant thrives in alpine and rocky environments, where it is adapted to cold and harsh conditions. It produces small, showy flowers that bloom in late spring or early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its hardy nature, it is often cultivated in gardens as an ornamental plant.
